comment_text:
Trevor is a young man who has decided to pursue technical photography full time. He's all in. His current plan to grow this career via Patreon. His contribution to this project was irreplaceable. He volunteered to help make this video by proposing it to me several months ago and emailing me the coordinates, not knowing that we were already working on it with my buddy Matt Whitman who was miraculously able to get us access. When I told Trevor at the end of this project that it was likely he would have several more Patrons as a result of this effort, it was clear that it had not even crossed his mind. It is my sincere hope that this YouTube comment enables him to pursue a career in technical photography by pairing up hundreds of willing contributors to his work. He photographs Space-X launches, and all things aerospace..... seriously...he was introduced to me by an astronaut. This young man is legit, and his work will not disappoint you. He is going places, and it would be awesome if you checked out his stuff and decided if it's worth investing in someone who is humble and works hard. Also, he can print this picture for you.

Please consider supporting Trevor at: https://www.patreon.com/trevormahlmann
At the time of this comment, Trevor is driving across the wilds of Wyoming without cell phone coverage and he has 29 Patrons.

Honestly, the landowners' description of weird was literally the best description of the eclipse having seen it just outside Carbondale, IL. When we were at Smoky Mtn  Nat. Park for the eclipse, we were fortunate enough to have brought a big enough piece of solar filter material (the solar lens film) to set up our telescope. We quickly realized that we could get pictures of the eclipse on our phones by lining up the lens carefully. Most if not all of the other telescope setups were either professional of academic setups. We were just there. Soon after that, someone nearby asked if they could get a picture on THEIR phone. Obviously we said sure! After that, I think we helped at least half a dozen or more people get some great images. It made the whole experience even better! My husband got a Corona image that I've suggested multiple times he try entering into a photography contest.

This video is a fake for the following mathematical facts and reasoning.
Fact 1:
The space station is recorded as taking 92 minutes to orbit earth.
Fact 2:
The angular size of the sun is approx 0.5 degrees

Reasoning
For the Space Station pass 1 degree it will take 92 minutes divide by 360 deg rees
= approx 0.25 minutes or 15 seconds per degree

Time to pass 0.3 deg is 15 seconds times 0.3
= 4.5 seconds

Fact 3:
IT SHOULD HAVE TAKEN ABOUT 4 SECONDS FOR THE SPACE STATION TO PASS THE SUN WHERE IT DID

Fact 4:
The transit of the space station in the video was less than a second.

Conclusion
The video is a fake

Total eclipse happen during the new moon phase. You can never see the moon during this phase outside of a solar eclipse. In fact, you can never see a new moon because it's on the wrong side of its orbit to even be seen at night. It's in new moon phase during early sunrise, throughout the day and then early sunset, so there aren't even many stars to be a back drop to spot the tiny circle in the sky being blocked by the moon.

This is one of my favorite videos in all of YouTube! I told my family I would be friends with all you guys! Love interesting and happy people! Ya gotta love life!!

We picked our spot in a hilltop cornfield in North Central Tennessee just south of Kentucky.

Played Moonshadow by Cat Stevens just before totality, and then heard ""Hello darkness my old friend" Sounds of Silence (Original 1964 version) by Simon & Garfunkel during the eclipse, followed by ""Here comes the Sun" by The Beatles! It was great having an epic eclipse soundtrack, and all 30 or so songs are part of our memory for that great wonderful day.
Was just myself and my young daughter, and this day was one of my favorite times in life.
Managed to somehow video the eclipse with my phone without wiping my camera lens, but just like you, I was living in the moment and have no regrets. It came out ok. I got weird too! LOL
#Life
See you guys on April 8th, 2024 God willing, in Indiana, or Ohio, or if the clouds hinder, maybe Quebec or Maine!
If there is any interest in our YouTube Solar Eclipse music playlist, just reply below and I'll post it. It was a huge part of our day and the music brings us back.

73

I went to Crab Orchard Wildlife Refuge in Marion Illinois with my Mom and sister. We were there with about 150-200 people and when totality came there was dead silence even from the little kids who were there. The sounds were very strange. Crickets chirping, owls hooting. The cheers came when the diamond ring formed at the end. Can't wait for 2024 (where Carbondale Ill. gets totality AGAIN) and hopefully be around for 2045 because two and a half minutes of seeing that hole in the sky was simply not enough! Now I understand why people chase these all over the world!

Hey Destin, awesome catch on the ISS transit! Thanks for listing your gear above. Is there a chance you could do a video outlining the gear, setup and use? I captured a video of the entire eclipse near Syracuse New York (68% coverage). I edited down the footage using motion control in Premiere Elements to keep the image centered then time lapsed it from 2 1/2 hours down to 2 1/2 minutes. I used a JVC GY-HM-600U video camera with a Baader Planetarium safety film (OD=5.0) filter I made with a couple of camera filter step-up rings. The image was ok, but no where near the clarity of your images. I uploaded it to my YouTube channel. Feel free to check it out. Thanks for sharing so many interesting concepts on your channels.

We went into Newberry, SC for totality. We almost missed it due to 2 truckers intentionally slowing traffic from 70mph (speed limit) down to 45mph on I-77. We made it though, intended to be there at 1pm we ended up getting there at 2:05pm. I really, really appreciate all the videos you made concerning this eclipse. I took my daughter and step children with me to view it.

The reactions from those 3 kids I think was better than witnessing it myself. My duaghter started crying, and wouldnt look at it until I sat with her and showed her there was nothing to be afraid of. My step son, had his jaw wide open, and my 18 yr old step daughter... Her reaction was priceless "Oh...My...GOD!".... I know these kids will remember this the rest of their life, I know I sure will. Im sitting here teary eyed, because its two days later, and I am still in awe. The entire trip to SC, while short, was completely awesome.

A little fact about Newberry, SC and why I choose that viewing party was the fact that they call their small town, the center of the universe. So I found it fitting, and for 1 day, it really did seem to be the center of the universe! I could go on and on about all the really cool things I saw during the eclipse down there, especially during totality, so ill save that for discussions in the replies.

I felt that exact same awe when totality struck. I almost dropped everything I was doing.

I'd seen a partial a number of years ago but the total was very different. It was a much more intense, awe inspiring experience. The effects on the everything around was very evident. It went dead silent, the wind stopped, fish in the lake began jumping. It was like someone hit the mute button. The effect on people surprised me. Many people were in tears. People who were dragged along, went out of obligation and had no real interest in being there suddenly were standing up looking at totality with their mouths agape and tears running down their cheeks. It's an overused word but "awesome" is the only way I can describe it. I can absolutely understand why people spend thousands of dollars chasing eclipses around the world. An unforgettable day.

So, I am going to sound like a right idiot when I get the explanation, but, I am confused on the 360 degree sunset when totality happens.

What confuses me is when a normal sunset happens, what I understand is that on the horizon, the light I see that turns orange and other colors, is still from the sun. It's just over the horizon bouncing off of the atmosphere and back to us, which is why it changes colors. So when a 360 degree "sunset" happened, where is the light coming from?

I understand that you can see landscape in the distance because light bounces off the ground and back to you, but on the horizon, is it because the light refracts off the atmosphere at an angle and the same wavelength that is reflected on a normal sunset also reflects during this event? Sorry If I don't make sense, maybe someone can translate my illiterate question to English. :^)

You're lucky. I could have stayed in Lincoln, Ne, where I live and currently go to UNL, but my family decided to go to a scout camp we love that was perfectly located and open for the eclipse. It was a perfect location, but the clouds fought tooth and nail. Before totality, you could just see the sun peek through occasionally. Just before it happened, one more cloud crossed in the way! It was there literally until the instant the app said C3, totality was over, and from then on, we could see perfectly! We just barely missed seeing the totality! I mean, I don't really care, it was a beautiful experience, we saw plenty and only missed one part of the entire eclipse, but we'll see it on the next one. That spot was so beautiful, though, and when it got dark and the birds and coyotes and frogs called out, it was great enough as it was that I'm not upset about not seeing that one part. I kind of wish I had, but I'm not beating myself up.

I listened to your podcast on my drive down from NJ to TN to see totality and later on Monday wondered if you were going to catch the transit. Glad you did. Also so happy for all the eclipse videos you put out there. The app worked great and I saw shadowbands both 40 seconds before and 40 seconds after totality. I picked my spot on the centerline based on best cloud cover predictions that morning and there were maybe 400 really cool folks who converged on the same spot many bringing lots of equipment. It was quite a star party. There was one group who said that this was their 8th total eclipse and they were so happy when I pointed out the shadowbands when they appeared since they had never been lucky enough to see them before. This was my first time in totality and it was amazing - it's something I wanted to do since I was 6 back in 1984 and was forced to stay inside with blinds drawn even though I had built my pinhole camera based on a science magazine - think it was 321 Contact. Well anyway, thanks for all you do Destin and keep up the amazing work!

"I totally botched up my photography. I don't really care." That about sums it up for me too. I did learn two valuable lessons for the future, though.

1) Welder's glass is not a good substitute for a proper solar film sheet. It wasn't my plan to use this for my cameras, but I bought my solar film and glasses from a shady dealer on Amazon and was forced to put together a last minute DIY solution. Our brains do a great job of filtering out the imperfections in this kind of glass (the dark spots and the lines), but cameras are not. I am still proud of my home made filter harness and shroud, though. If you would like to see it, message me for a photo.

2) Tape down that focus ring. I took my harness and shroud off to take an unfiltered series of photos for the composite image I was trying to get. When I put the harness and shroud back on, I must have nudged the focus ring because everything after that point (all that mattered) was blurry.

I did see the shadow bands with my own eyes and I am so glad you managed to capture it camera. Well done!

And thank you for your original video. It was an essential part of my eclipse planning and helped fuel my enthusiasm.

Destin, my five year old sat on my lap in our backyard in Paducah KY. He was enthralled by the eclipse and when we told him that he could take his glasses off, he started to shake with excitement. After preparing for months to watch this from home, no picture could ever take the place of that memory. I will always see that look of awe in his face. Great pictures, the ISS transit, and the best moments with your wife and kids (and Matt's family as well).
